info.headline: Red Flag Warning issued August 08 at 3:28AM PDT until August 09 at 9:00PM PDT by NWS Medford
info.description: ...Periods of Critical Conditions Expected Across Portions of Southern Oregon and Northern California... .The next couple of days will see periods of critical conditions consisting of strong gusty wind and low RH today for portions of Siskiyou County as well as thunderstorms capable of producing frequent lightning in scattered showers along and east of the Cascades. While the thunderstorms will likely become isolated overnight tonight, they are expected to pick up in activity once again on Tuesday. Additional periods of gusty winds and low humidities will also be possible on Tuesday for portions of Siskiyou and Jackson Counties. ...RED FLAG WARNING REMAINS IN EFFECT FROM 2 PM THIS AFTERNOON TO 9 PM PDT TUESDAY FOR ABUNDANT LIGHTNING ON DRY FUELS FOR FIRE WEATHER ZONE 624... The National Weather Service in Medford has cancelled the Fire Weather Watch. * Impacts: Lightning and very dry vegetation will likely result in new fire starts. Gusty thunderstorm winds could contribute to quick fire spread. Despite rainfall, initial attack resources could be overwhelmed and holdover fires are possible. * Affected area: On Monday, almost all of fire weather zone 624. The threat area for thunderstorms shifts a bit more to the north and east on Tuesday. * Wind: South 10 to 15 mph with gusts up to 30 mph on Tuesday. * Humidity: As low as 10 percent on Tuesday. * Thunderstorms: Thunderstorm activity will likely begin by mid- afternoon Monday with the most active period likely in the late afternoon and evening. Activity could linger at night and into Tuesday, shifting east and north with time. Storms will also become wetter by Tuesday. * Additional Details: Despite the thunderstorm lifting to the north and east with time on Tuesday, critical conditions are expected to shift from the thunderstorm threat to that of gusty winds and low RH for southwestern portion of zone 624 including Klamath Falls and surrounding areas on Tuesday. * View the hazard area in detail at: https://www.wrh.noaa.gov/mfr/HAZARD Precautionary/preparedness actions... Avoid tossing burning cigarettes on the ground, parking hot vehicles on dry vegetation, and using equipment that can cause sparks. Follow all fire restrictions. Find links to restrictions at weather.gov/medford/wildfire. One less spark, one less wildfire. Gather your fire evacuation kit now. Collect essentials you don`t want to lose and prioritize your checklist. Visit ready.gov/kit for more information. Familiarize yourself with your evacuation plan. Where will you go? How will you get there? Who will you call to let others know your are safe? Visit ready.gov/wildfires for more information. A Red Flag Warning does not mean there is a fire. It means that critical fire weather conditions are either occurring now or will shortly. These conditions promote rapid spread of fire which may become life threatening. Evacuate if ordered to, or if a fire threatens. &&
